theories.card_other: Flow of electric charge through conductor. Rate of charge flow. Conventional direction: positive to negative (opposite to electron flow). SI unit: ampere (A). 1 A = 1 C/s. Requires closed circuit and potential difference.

Average velocity of charge carriers in conductor due to electric field. Very slow (~10⁻⁴ m/s) despite fast electron motion. Current depends on drift velocity, not random thermal velocity. Proportional to applied field.

Current through conductor proportional to voltage, inversely proportional to resistance. V = IR. Valid for ohmic materials at constant temperature. Not universal law - semiconductors and diodes are non-ohmic.
Opposition to current flow. Depends on material (resistivity), length (longer = more resistance), and cross-section (wider = less resistance). SI unit: ohm (Ω). Converts electrical energy to heat.

Intrinsic property of material indicating resistance to current. Independent of shape/size. Temperature dependent - increases with temperature for metals, decreases for semiconductors. SI unit: Ω·m. Symbol: ρ.
Reciprocal of resistivity. Measure of how easily material conducts current. High in metals (good conductors), low in insulators. SI unit: S/m (siemens per meter). Symbol: σ.

Resistance of metals increases with temperature due to increased atomic vibrations. Semiconductors show opposite behavior. Superconductors have zero resistance below critical temperature. Temperature coefficient α describes rate of change.

Phenomenon where certain materials have zero electrical resistance below critical temperature. Discovered by Kamerlingh Onnes. Allows persistent currents without energy loss. Used in MRI machines, particle accelerators.
Same current flows through all. Total voltage divided among resistors. Equivalent resistance equals sum: Req = R₁ + R₂ + ... Increases total resistance. Used in voltage dividers.
Same voltage across all. Total current divided among paths. Equivalent resistance less than smallest: 1/Req = 1/R₁ + 1/R₂ + ... Decreases total resistance. Provides multiple paths for current.
Energy per unit charge supplied by battery or generator. Despite name, not a force - measured in volts. Maximum potential difference when no current flows. Maintains current by doing work on charges.
Resistance within battery/cell itself. Causes voltage drop when current flows. Terminal voltage less than EMF due to internal resistance. Increases as battery ages. Limits maximum current.
Actual voltage across battery terminals when current flows. Equals EMF minus voltage drop across internal resistance. Less than EMF when discharging. Measured by voltmeter.
Sum of currents entering junction equals sum leaving. Consequence of charge conservation. Applies to any node in circuit. Essential for analyzing complex circuits.
Sum of voltage changes around any closed loop is zero. Consequence of energy conservation. Sum of EMFs equals sum of voltage drops. Used with KCL to solve circuit problems.
Circuit for measuring unknown resistance precisely. Balanced when no current through galvanometer. At balance: P/Q = R/X. More accurate than direct measurement. Used in strain gauges, sensors.
Device for measuring EMF without drawing current. Uses null method - more accurate than voltmeter. Can compare EMFs or measure internal resistance. Based on potential gradient along wire.
Rate of electrical energy conversion. P = VI = I²R = V²/R. Unit: watt (W). Heat dissipated in resistor converted from electrical energy. Important for rating appliances and preventing overheating.
Heat produced in resistor proportional to square of current, resistance, and time. H = I²Rt. Basis of electric heaters, bulbs, fuses. Can be unwanted (energy loss) or useful (heating elements).
Unit of electrical energy used by power companies. 1 kWh = 3.6 × 10⁶ J. Energy consumed by 1 kW device running for 1 hour. Appears on electricity bills.
Safety device with wire that melts if current exceeds rating. Protects circuits from overcurrent damage. Single-use (must be replaced) unlike circuit breakers. Rated by maximum safe current.
Increases total EMF (voltages add). Same current through all cells. Total internal resistance increases. Used when higher voltage needed. Batteries are cells in series.
Same EMF as single cell. Can supply larger current (divided among cells). Internal resistance decreases. Used when higher current capacity needed. Increases battery life.
Instrument measuring current. Connected in series with component. Low resistance (ideally zero) to not affect current. Can be converted from galvanometer using shunt resistor.

Instrument measuring potential difference. Connected in parallel across component. High resistance (ideally infinite) to draw minimal current. Can be converted from galvanometer using high series resistance.
Instrument measuring resistance. Must be used with power off in circuit. Contains own battery. Can check continuity (very low resistance). Based on Ohm's law.
